title: Firefighter, 59, killed by falling tree was 'experienced' national parks worker
text:
A 59-year-old national parks firefighter has died after he was hit by a tree while fighting a bushfire north of Newcastle in NSW.

The "absolutely devastating﻿" death of the veteran firefighter happened around 11pm yesterday at Little Nugra Road in Nerong.

He had a heart attack after the tree fell, with colleagues desperately trying to save him.

A 59-year-old national parks firefighter has died after he was hit by a tree while fighting a bushfire north of Newcastle in NSW. (Media Response Newcastle.)

"The firefighter was a field officer with the National Parks and Wildlife Service, and he started working for National Parks in 1996," Environment Minister Penny Sharpe said.

"He was an experienced firefighter and divisional commander.﻿

"Our dedicated National Parks staff show courage and commitment every day when they put on the uniform, they go out to protect all of us.

"And, unfortunately, on this occasion, one person hasn't come home."

RFS Commissioner Trent Curtain said "our hearts go out to his family, to his friends, and to our colleagues".

He said the loss would be felt "deeply".

﻿He said a backburn was being done as part of the Bulahdelah fire, which started last week on the NSW Mid North Coast and is now 3500 hectares in size.

The firefighter was checking on colleagues when the tree fell.

There are around 1000 NSW National Parks firefighters working alongside the RFS and Fire and Rescue.﻿

Four homes have been lost in that fire.

Premier Chris Minns told ﻿ Today the man's family was being contacted.

"We're heartbroken by this news," he said.

"It's devastating and it's a reminder of what keeps the public safe.

"This is many ways a dangerous profession, and we're deeply indebted to the men and women that devote their time to keeping us safe."

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the firefighter's death was "terrible news" in a statement on social media.

"My heart goes out to the loved ones and colleagues of the firefighter who has tragically lost their life in the Bulahdelah bushfire," he posted on X.

At least 18 homes were damaged or destroyed in another fast-moving bushfire last Saturday in Koolewong, north of Sydney. (Nine)

A man surveys the damage from the Koolewong bushfire. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

"All Australians are thinking of you in your time of grief. This terrible news is a sombre reminder of the dangers that our emergency services﻿."

Police have set up a crime scene and WorkSafe has been notified.

A report will be prepared for the coroner.

At least 18 homes were damaged or destroyed in another fast-moving bushfire on Saturday in Koolewong, a small waterside suburb near Woy Woy on the NSW Central Coast.

Locals told how fast the ferocious flames came for the waterside houses.﻿

The NSW Rural Fire Service, in an update today, said 52 fires are continuing to burn.

Around 500 firefighters are out working.﻿

A Sikorsky S-61 helicopter tackles the Koolewong bushfire. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

Craig Saxon and Sarra Saxon-Gill return to see their destroyed home on the NSW Central Coast. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

Among fires burning is a large fire north of Redhead, a coastal suburb of Lake Macquarie council, on the western side of Redhead Road and south of Oakdale Road . ﻿

The blaze spans 64 hectares, but is in the process of being controlled.﻿

Residents in the areas of Dudley and Whitebridge and Gateshead are being advised to monitor conditions in case the situation changes.

title: The Aussie city with the best Uber rating revealed
text:
The Gold Coast has been named the city with the best rideshare passengers, having the top Uber rider rating.

The city had an average rating of 4.88 out of five, level with the Sunshine Coast and Cairns as Queensland had a clean sweep of best rider rating across the country, according to data released by the company.

Of the state capitals, Hobart had the best rating with 4.85, whilst Sydney was marginally ahead of Melbourne and Brisbane.

Some major cities shone, whilst others floundered in the end of year ratings. (Supplied)

The harbour city's riders had an average rating of 4.83, just above the national average of 4.82, with Brisbane and Melbourne stuck on 4.80.

Perth and Adelaide were down at the bottom of the list with the worst rider rating, with both states also found at the bottom of the rankings released today.

The Northern Territory topped this list, with New South Wales slipping from first to third.

The rating system on Uber is two-way, with both riders and drivers able to give ratings for each other.

It is based off of the last 500 trips a rider has taken, meaning it can change quickly.

Passengers with a lower rating may find it harder to get a ride accepted by a driver.

Both drivers and riders are required to follow Uber's community guidelines, which include following the law, treating drivers and passengers with respect, and keeping safety front of mind at all times.

title: 'We just cried': Stenson breaks marathon record in emotional scenes
text:
Jessica Stenson has been left in tears after breaking the Australian marathon record in Spain.

Commonwealth champion Stenson set a new national landmark of 2 hours, 21 minutes and 25 seconds at the Valencia Marathon to slice nine seconds off her friend Sinead Diver's record of 2:21.34.

On one of the world's fastest courses, the 38-year-old veteran enjoyed the race of her life to finish fifth, shattering her own personal best of 2:22:56 by a minute-and-a-half.

"I just got off the phone to Sinead, she called me right away and we just cried," Stenson said.

"She was so happy for me, and it was so nice to connect with her after the race.

"I'm so delighted and so satisfied. Everyone's always said Valencia is a magic place to run but I have to admit, I was really nervous coming into this race because I knew I was going to have a crack at the record and that it was going to hurt.

"I was expecting a lot of pain — mental pain more than anything — but it was one of those days that I was pleasantly surprised and I found my flow."

On track for the record throughout the race, Stenson made sure by surging through the final kilometres.

She crossed the line with a roar of delight as she enjoyed another magic moment in a career which has taken in three Olympics.

Running her third marathon of the year, Stenson also paid tribute to 48-year-old Diver, who had set her record four years ago.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"I'm so grateful for Sinead and that record she set," Stenson said.

"When there was one kilometre left, I was thinking of her and trying to squeeze as much as I could out of myself, knowing what was possible to achieve.

"I have the highest level of respect for her, so she was there with me in a positive way."

Up ahead, Kenyan Joyciline Jepkosgei won the race in a world-leading time of 2:14:00 — the fourth-fastest time in history by a woman — ahead of compatriot Peres Jepchirchir, who finished second, 43 seconds behind.

Kenya also celebrated victory in the men's race with John Korir winning in 2:02:24, bettering his personal best by 20 seconds. Thomas Do Canto was the first Australian home, clocking 2:11:14 for 40th place.

title: Perth's new bin rules bring maggots and bad smells to angry residents
text:
Residents in outer Perth say they are dealing with an "infestation of maggots" and rotting rubbish after the introduction of a third bin for food and garden waste.

The City of Rockingham recently brought in the so-called "FOGO" (food organics garden organics) system — a three-bin service the WA government is keen to see implemented metropolitan-wide.

It has been criticised by councils and residents in the state's south-west, where all the waste from the organics bin has been going to landfill for a year because of high levels of contamination.

When the City of Rockingham introduced the FOGO bin in June, it cut back red bin collection to fortnightly in line with WA Waste Authority guidelines and committed to a weekly FOGO pick-up.

There are concerns the maggots and flies will only get worse over summer. (Supplied)

Father-of-two Daniel Prowse said it was problematic.

"There is still a fair amount of waste in our household that would go in the red bin, particularly from our two-year-old who is in nappies," he said

" Human waste in your bin for two weeks is pretty on the nose and no matter what you did … it was always fly-ridden, absolutely stunk and just [had] maggots. "

He said he was happy for FOGO to continue, but wanted red bins to be collected weekly.

Daniel Prowse and his family moved to the City of Rockingham just before the new bin system was introduced. (Supplied: Daniel Prowse)

As a mother of two young children, Clare Lee said her bins were "overflowing" well before collection time.

"It's just not enough space, and then you factor in relatives coming to stay and events like Christmas," she said.

"The council needs to be educated on the reality of what it means for families."

Families with kids in nappies say their red bins are "overflowing" every fortnight. (Supplied)

'No plans' for change

City of Rockingham Mayor Lorna Buchan has shut down calls from the community for changes.

"The city has no plans to revert to weekly red-lidded bin general waste collection," she said

"[The city] joins more than 25 other local government authorities in Western Australia that have already successfully adopted this approach to greatly reduce the amount of waste being sent to landfill.

"To help manage odours … residents are encouraged to wrap these items securely before disposal, using biodegradable bags where possible, and keep their bin sealed and in a shaded area."

In the past month, the city said more than 95 per cent of the FOGO waste collected had been processed.

The City of Rockingham says it has no plans to revert to weekly red bin collection. (Suppied: City of Rockingham)

'Failing' on rubbish

Long-time resident Simon Brown said the "maggot infestation" would only get worse over the summer.

"The first principles of any local government are roads, rates and rubbish, and Rockingham council is really failing on the rubbish part," he said.

"I have not seen a maggot infestation like that … I have never seen so many crows in my life; they are well fed and pulling all the rubbish out of the bins."

Simon Brown says the council is failing to deliver on one of its core responsibilities to ratepayers. (Supplied: Simon Brown)

He said the council needed to look at "lessons learnt" in other areas.

"We're turning a blind eye to the failures of FOGO in other local governments [and] shoving our heads in the sand," Mr Brown said.

FOGO still no-go in state's South West

In WA's South West, some residents missing their food organics bins are being offered rebates to set up their own composts or worm farms.

A year ago, the FOGO system was put on hold in the region, and some councils are considering pulling the plug due to their FOGO waste being sent to landfill.

Processor Bunbury Harvey Regional Council is working on a solution.

The Shire of Augusta-Margaret River started offering rebates to residents who want to make worm-farms or compost at home. (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch)

In the Shire of Augusta-Margaret River, frustration with organics going to landfill prompted the council to bring in rebates of up to $80.

In two months, 45 people have accepted the offer.

Sustainability officer Kate Jameson said it was great to see residents taking matters into their own hands.

"Because of that happening, that has brought a lot more interest from people in looking at other ways they can dispose of their waste responsibly," she said.

" It's great to see already that we've had such a high uptake in the rebate. "

In nearby Busselton, the city has held off introducing the organics bin, despite most of the South West jumping on board years ago.

City of Busselton local Valerie Frearson-Lane hopes FOGO issues can be sorted out. (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch)

Resident Valerie Frearson-Lane had been home-composting, but said she hoped the issues with the FOGO bin could be ironed out for others.

"It would be good if people could be encouraged to do it themselves, but not everyone is interested," she said.

"I'd really like the FOGO system if that can be made to work."

title: Coach says England 'over-prepared' as players go on Noosa getaway
text:
England coach Brendon McCullum has claimed his team trained too hard for the Gabba Test, which ended in a bruising eight-wicket loss that leaves the tourists' Ashes hopes in tatters.

England's training regime has been a point of focus since the team arrived in Australia, with only internal fixtures and no official practice match scheduled ahead of their first-Test loss in Perth.

Heading into the crucial pink-ball Test in Brisbane, Australia had played and won three day-night matches since England's last one in 2023.

But the entire XI from the loss in Perth opted to skip out on playing in a day-night tour match against the Prime Minister's XI in Canberra and head straight to Brisbane.

The decision prompted questions as to whether five days training in Brisbane was the best preparation for a clash with the day-night masters.

As "Bazball" architect McCullum saw it, England had the opposite issue.

"I actually felt like we over-prepared to be honest," McCullum said.

"I think sometimes when you're in the heat of the battle, as we all know, sometimes the most important thing is to feel a bit fresh."

England will have that chance to freshen up when they head to Noosa for a getaway before the third Test match that begins in Adelaide on December 17.

Paparazzi are set to be out in force trying to catch the tourists lounging around in the sun as their Ashes hopes hang by a thread.

The team already received plenty of scrutiny from the Australian press in Brisbane when three players, including captain Ben Stokes, were photographed riding e-scooters without helmets.

Stokes said the Sunshine Coast sojourn would be a chance for a much-needed physical and mental break.

"We have been here four weeks and they have been pretty full on," Stokes said.

How the internet reacted to the Aussies going 2-0 up Mitchell Starc was the hero, again, as the English were comprehensively outplayed in Brisbane — but how did the internet react?

"As physical as this game is, a huge part of it is also the mental side of it. I know that. I have experienced that. I know what the game can do to you when things aren't quite feeling right or going well.

"It is so important when teams, when they do get an occasion or opportunity, go away as a team and put the pressures of this aside for a couple of days."

Asked for his opinion on McCullum's over-preparation comment, Stokes said England needed to prioritise training smarter, not harder.

"There is a great saying that I know: 'Are you going to train to train or train to dominate?'," Stokes said.

"There is a lot of training that you see going on where you are doing it for the sake of doing it and not achieving anything.

"On the back of the first Test match, when we desperately want something like we do, maybe you can fall into that 'train to train'. I have been guilty of that myself. But I like to train to dominate."

title: How the internet reacted to the Aussies going 2-0 up
text:
Australia have taken a commanding 2-0 lead in the Ashes, and in some style at the Gabba. The English were outplayed comprehensively, and Mitchell Starc was their destroyer-in-chief.

Here's how the internet reacted to the second Test.

Day one

Nathan Lyon was dropped for Michael Neser the morning of day one — 562 Test wickets removed in the blink of an eye.

And like a rubber band on a sheep, the Neser inclusion also shortened the Australian tail.

England won the toss, and elected to bat, Zak Crawley faced the first ball from Starc, and let it pass through to Alex Carey; the next two balls beat the bat, and fourth was struck handsomely to the boundary.

After such a long break between Tests, it was a wonderful feeling to see battle resume.

And Starc landed the first pulverising blow, another wicket in his first over, Duckett, for a golden duck.

In his next over, Starc had Pope chopping onto his stumps, also for a duck.

England were yet again stumbling and groping wildly for something with which to steady themselves; Joe Root trotted out hoping to offer them that.

Crawley was in attack mode, and although one suspects the switch on his back is permanently jammed thusly, he was keeping England from keeling over entirely, playing some fine shots around the ground, through the air and along the grass.

England brought up their 52 balls quicker than they did in Perth, more fast-forward cricket.

Root was being very sensible, and save for a very difficult chance dropped by Steve Smith early on, he was looking assured at the crease.

When the partnership reached 100-odd balls, it made it the longest of the series so far, by either team.

It felt like England were comfortably on top, but were still 2-84; Bazball, and the hyper-mode version we saw in Perth, seems to have disrupted the normal internal Test cricket intuitions.

You have to shake yourself free of its dizzying grips to remember how Test cricket usually feels, it's not some madcap dash where wickets fall in great juicy bunches and batters swing their bats from ankle to shoulder like heaving scythes.

Crawley brought up his 50, after two ducks in the first Test, a fine response indeed. England were settled, 2-98 at lunch.

Crawley set about racing toward his ton after lunch, hitting boundary after boundary, but was undone on 76 by a Neser ball that he feathered through to Carey.

Harry Brook came in, scored a quick 16 off 11 balls, and was nearly stumped playing a ramp shot; traditionalists' molars were being ground down to dusty nubs around the UK, but it was fun to watch.

Root, meanwhile, got his half-century, halfway to that elusive ton on these shores.

Some pressure was built by Scott Boland, and then Starc, coming back in, took out Brook, nicking wildly to Smith. That wicket took Starc into the all-time lead for Test wickets by a left arm quick.

The run-rate had been squashed slightly, the pace of the game was slowing, but Root and now Ben Stokes were largely untroubled, and the ball was soft.

Then a disastrous Stokes run-out, where he took off for a run and was sent back, saw Josh Inglis throw the wicket down on the run with a single stump to aim at, a superb piece of fielding. Stokes was furious with himself.

Boland then bowled Jamie Smith minutes later, and what had been a firm English grip on the match turned clammy and began to slip.

But Root was still there, the port in the storm for England, and he was creeping toward his century.

Will Jacks decided to liven things up by slashing an edge to Smith off Starc with Root on 98.

"That was not a clever bit of cricket from Jacks," said Jim Maxwell.

Root, as he had all day, put the blinkers on those ice blue eyes and kept going, and he crashed through that milestone barrier that had kept him out for so long.

It was a joyous moment for English fans, but sudden wickets put a stop to it, as Starc picked up two more, one courtesy of a stunning catch by Carey that resembled more a contested Aussie Rules mark than any cricketing action.

Jofra Archer made a flashy entrance, swinging wildly and scoring well too — Stokes clearly had no intention of declaring to have a crack at the Aussie openers under lights, and was happy to have Archer and Root tonk the ball around the Gabba.

And the final wicket partnership survived the evening, added 61 runs, a very valuable contribution indeed.

Starc finished with six wickets, another Trojan performance where he carried the bowling without his three colleagues in Cummins, Hazlewood, and Lyon. But it was Root's day, and as he walked off the ground, the Australian team all shook his hand.

Day two

The day resumed with Australia needing a single wicket to get before they could take to this pitch with the bat.

It took Labuschagne turning into SuperMarn, taking a flying catch to dismiss Archer, to end the innings.

With Usman Khawaja still laid up with an iffy back, Travis Head walked out again with Jake Weatherald.

Head and Weatherald got Australia off to a good start, a partnership of 77, ended by a top edge that Head skied to a fielder.

But Weatherald went on with it, racing to a 50 off 45 balls, and Marnus came in with similar intent. They punished some wayward England bowling and Australia were 1-130 at lunch.

Weatherald was cruising after the break, but a venomous Jofra Archer yorker crashed into his toe, and he walked off without even reviewing, for a very stylish 72.

Steve Smith entered, and with Marnus there with him, the twitch-off began, idiosyncratic spasms abounded, as if the Aussie batters were being bitten by a great number of aggressive fleas between every delivery. Marnus eventually got out slashing at a wide ball.

Without the spurts of chaos that the English team provide when they bat, the placid nature of this wicket was revealed, as Smith and Cameron Green went to work scoring steadily, patiently and — save for a few typically flamboyant Smith shots -- in an orthodox manner.

The most interesting moment was when the England team asked for the ball to be looked at, more echoes of outrages past.

Then the contest suddenly woke up in a single Carse over, as Green backed away expecting a bouncer, and was bowled by a yorker. Then the new man Alex Carey was dropped, a simple chance, by Duckett. But Carse then took out Steve Smith, his pull-shot spectacularly caught by Will Jacks.

Out of nothing, England had the two set batters dismissed, and their vigour was refreshed.

The England team were lively, creating chance, but dropping more than they took; for every Jacks screamer, there was Carse putting down a chest-high dolly to give Neser a reprieve.

"I've noted five catches put down today," said Ric Finlay, ABC statistician.

"That's a lot of catches," replied Alison Mitchell.

Australia strode into the lead as the match stretched late into the evening; they had batted very well, more steadily, a collection of solid double-figure contributions. 6-378, and lead of 44, at stumps.

England trudged off.

Day three

Australia wanted to push the lead to triple figures, but Neser departing early, and then Alex Carey not long after England took the new ball, meant the recognised batters were gone within an hour.

Starc was then the one to whom the run-making duties fell, and he was up to the task, scoring patiently, protecting Scott Boland from taking the strike too often, and further cementing his place as Australia's most valuable player in this series so far.

After lunch, Starc got his 50. Boland blocked his way to double figures. This was the slowest-scoring period of play for the entire series, but it was superb fun for the Australian fans.

Starc went on, he went into the 60s, the 70s, past Jake Weatherald to become the top scorer in the innings for his team, and all the while the Australian lead swelled, as did the beads of sweat on the English collective brow.

He was out for 77, his third-highest Test score. He walked off to an uproarious ovation.

And it wasn't over for England, as Brendan Doggett also made it to double figures, meaning every Australian batter had scored 10 or more, the first time that had happened since 1992.

Australia finished up having made 511, a lead of 177.

Would England look to survive the night, to defend, to preserve? No, Crawley and Duckett set out to attack, and were going at better than a run a ball when tea arrived.

Scott Boland got the breakthrough in his first over after the resumption, bowling Ben Duckett for 15, a ball that kept so low it clipped the toe of the bat before crashing into the stumps.

England were scoring well, but in a typically haphazard way, with Ollie Pope slashing hard into the air and only barely missing diving fielders. His luck ran out when he eventually drove straight to Neser, out caught and bowled.

Incredibly, that was the exact same way Crawley got out a few overs later, caught and bowled chipping a drive to Neser.

And then the big one; Joe Root. Starc got him nicking to Carey for 15. The first innings hero who carried his bat for England was back in the sheds for a meagre total, his team now four down and still 56 runs away from making the hosts bat again.

A few overs later, Boland had Brook nicking to Carey, also for just 15.

"That could be your lot, England," said Phil Tufnell on the ABC Sport call.

And it was; England ended the day six wickets down, and still 43 runs short of Australia's total.

Day four

Two types of English fans woke up on day four, feeling two different ways.

Stokes and Jacks got to work, and displayed a huge amount of patience and control at the crease, scoring at around three runs an over, which for Bazball is basically the same as leaving every ball.

They chipped away admirably, and after an hour and a half, they crept out of the red into the lead, and began to attempt to build a lead they could defend.

Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne bowled back-to-back overs just before tea; you could almost hear the frantic calls of television directors around the stadium to direct the cameras toward Lyon's face. But England got through the first session unscathed.

The day stretched on, the English partnership seemed to harden with each wicketless over, and the visitors' hope grew. Then it was shattered by a piece of individual brilliance by the Australian captain.

Steve Smith, one of the greatest slip fielders of his era, took a bona fide screamer, diving and gripping to his left to secure a Jacks edge off the bowling of Neser.

Neser then got Stokes, who had just reached his half-century, and those broken shards of English hope began to bubble and hiss and evaporate into the Brisbane evening. It was an edge wonderfully taken by Alex Carey, who was up at the stumps.

The quality of the Australian fielding and wicketkeeping was in such stark contrast to the English effort, it was almost comical, every wicket Australia took resembled exactly the kind of chance the English would have wasted.

Ben Stokes punched himself in the helmet as he walked off, and a huge shower of bitter perspiration sprayed off his furrowed brow at the impact.

The wickets then fell quickly, Atkinson, then Carse, and the English were all out, with a lead of 64.

Head, Weatherald, Labuschagne and Smith made short work of the target. Smith even had time to have a bit of chirpy back-and-forth with Jofra Archer while hitting for 15 off an over.

There was a feeling the English supporters, and possibly the players and coaches, had, warm and soothing in the soul, when Stokes and Jacks were stolidly applying themselves with care and discretion in that first session.

It was a feeling that came not just because the batters were playing well, but how they were playing well. There was a security to that feeling, a sense of firm ground under your feet, instead of a frayed rope bridge over a ravine.

It was just normal, sensible cricket, no hijinks or mishaps, and it suited them. Had the top order played similarly the night before, maybe England wouldn't have lost this match, at least not so badly.

They could just simply play like this again, and enjoy that warm feeling once more, but the suspicion is they will actually choose not to.

Australia leads the Ashes 2-0.

title: Rain, hail or shine, Kevin would hitchhike 60km to work
text:
Western Australia's north is never short of a good yarn — if one knows where to look.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that the following article may contain images of people who have died.

Take the stranger at the roadside, his thumb stuck towards a sprawling night sky.

"Got up two or three in the morning, and then just wait out in the road probably two or three, four hours maybe before I get a ride to Dampier," Kevin Guiness recalled.

"Sometimes then I would start walking."

Mr Guiness would hitchhike to work from Roebourne as he did not own a car. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

For more than 25 years, the Yindjibarndi elder has travelled the dusty roads between some of Australia's largest and most lucrative industrial ports.

At 17, he landed an apprenticeship as a diesel mechanic at Rio Tinto's Dampier Salt project, about 1,530 kilometres north of Perth.

But his home in the Pilbara town of Roebourne was 60 kilometres away, and he did not own a car.

"I ended up hitchhiking from Roebourne to Dampier Salt," Mr Guiness said.

"Sometimes when it's raining, for my coat, I'd use a rubbish bag.

" It was still pitch dark, but I was just quite happy there waiting for a lift. "

Hitching through Pilbara history

Mr Guiness's journey began with the roar of an engine.

"I was seven years old and walking around with my dad and uncle," Mr Guiness said.

"We'd muck around with the old Land Rovers.

"My dad would maintain them and fix them up, and I would be there probably like an assistant."

Kevin Guiness (back row, second from right) moved from Mulga Downs to Wittenoom in the 1970s. (Supplied)

Mr Guiness was born on Mulga Downs Station at the foot of the Hamersley Ranges.

Dripping with pale spinifex yellows and deep earthy reds, the pastoral lease is often credited as the birthplace of the Pilbara mining industry.

It has long been held by the Hancock family: controversial patriarch Lang drove the region's first forays into blue asbestos and iron ore.

His daughter, Gina Rinehart, is still Australia's richest person.

Loading...

Life on Mulga Downs was hard, Mr Guiness said.

"Being out on the road, early hours of the morning, I think what … kept me going was my mum and dad.

"Because on the station, they work for nothing … basically tobacco and tea leaves.

"If my old people can do it for nothing, then I can do it for them."

Hard-earned lessons

Many Aboriginal people worked on Pilbara pastoral stations for little or no pay.

The stockman who turned 'black pennies' into an Indigenous stolen wages settlement Mervyn told the stories of his old people. They led to a $180m settlement for Aboriginal stolen wages.

Equal wages were only legislated by the Commonwealth in 1968, and exploitation remained rife through WA's north for years following.

The harsh conditions were not without their lessons.

By 12 years old, young Kevin could take apart and reassemble a car engine.

"You can put it [together] like a jigsaw puzzle," he said.

" If it's maybe a dead car, and then when you get it up and running and alive … you feel good. "

Mr Guiness first began working at Rio Tinto's Dampier Salt operations at 17. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

In search of better work, Mr Guiness's family moved to Wittenoom, where Lang Hancock opened a mine later catapulted into infamy.

When the town was closed amid the spread of asbestos-related disease, Mr Guiness relocated to Port Hedland and eventually Roebourne.

It was there he would spend years hitching rides to work.

"[At] six o'clock, we would knock off, then back on the highway," he said.

"By the time I get back home to Roebourne, it would be about 10 o'clock in the evening."

Recognised nationally

National construction company Tutt Bryant has named its inaugural apprentice of the year award after Mr Guiness, set to be awarded later in December.

"It's nothing short of inspirational, just what he's gone through … the odds that he faced in his own apprenticeship," managing director Chen Wei Ng told the ABC.

Kevin Guiness wants to inspire the next generation. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Tutt Bryant became aware of Mr Guiness's history during a now-defunct partnership with the Ngarluma-Yindjibarndi Foundation, where he was a director.

Mr Guiness hoped the prize would inspire the next generation of Indigenous tradespeople.

"The young people coming up, hopefully they look at it, and say, 'if Kevin can stay out on the road, I can do it, [I can] finish the apprenticeship,'" he said.

Rich 'in my own way'

Mr Guiness has not been able to shake the rhythms of his old commute.

"Even now I still wake up early, on my days off, up and about early [around] three o'clock," he said.

"It's part of the body clock now."

He still works at an iron ore port, balancing his vocation with traditional responsibilities.

Kevin Guiness is a Yindjibarndi elder. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Roebourne, or Ieramugadu, is home to a vibrant Aboriginal community, but elders there say social inequality and intergenerational disadvantage continue to be a challenge.

"In our culture, it's very important that we share what we got and that's what I've been doing with my family," Mr Guiness said.

"I'm sort of a rich in my own way … not so much a wealthy man, but I just got what I got."

These days, though, he catches the bus to Dampier.

title: WA's largest privately-owned power producer accused of hiking prices
text:
The cost of electricity is being driven up by tens of millions of dollars by some Western Australian power producers breaking the rules and charging more than they're allowed, the state's economic watchdog alleges.

In the latest alleged breach, WA's largest privately-owned generator, Bluewaters Power, hiked the wholesale price of electricity by about $30 million over eight months, the Economic Regulation Authority (ERA) claims.

Wholesale costs make up about 40 per cent of the average household power bill.

Just 13pc of rooftop solar capacity realised, advocates say Renewable energy advocates are urging the West Australian government to throw more of its weight behind rooftop solar and batteries, saying the state is running out of time to replace coal with large-scale green power projects.

In WA, the state government shields households from the immediate impacts of spikes in wholesale prices, but the more they happen, the more they can trickle down to bills.

A complex market

The ERA's chair Steve Edwell said the Bluewaters blowout was part of an "increasing number" of electricity generators using their power in a concentrated market to charge higher prices than they should.

Such behaviour is not allowed in WA as generators are only allowed to sell electricity to retailers, like Synergy, at-cost.

But the Japanese-owned company said its pricing was necessary to ensure it could reliably power the WA electricity grid, and argues its market impact was only a fraction of the $30 million claimed by the ERA.

"The alleged breaches relate to periods of time when Bluewaters faced coal and water shortages and was managing its generation," a Bluewaters spokesperson said.

Bluewaters Power Station was the first privately-owned, coal-fired power station in WA. (Supplied: Sumitomo)

Supply shortages can lead to reduced production capacity, which is often reflected in the market with higher prices.

Bluewaters claimed the ERA had "misunderstood the relevant facts" and incorrectly applied the law.

It follows another case earlier this year, where the ERA found Alinta had increased the cost of generation by $66 million over a similar time span, which the company is also disputing.

One thing both the regulator and industry can agree on is the market, and the rules, have become increasingly complex with the uptake of renewable energy.

Generators 'take advantage' of market

Nationally, the Australian Energy Regulator's (AER) last market report found electricity prices were staying relatively high despite increasing renewable generation, which is cheaper.

Seven WA energy retailers overcharged customers, inquiry finds Seven energy retailers in Western Australia has overcharged customers by taking automatic payments from closed accounts, an investigation finds.

That's in part because some generators were withholding electricity from the market, which can artificially drive up prices.

"Participants can take advantage of market conditions to make significant financial returns," the report said.

In a statement, an AER spokesperson said the practice of setting higher prices "cannot be false or misleading", but was otherwise allowed.

"However patterns of this kind of behaviour could lead to inefficiencies in the market and may not be in the best interests of energy consumers," the spokesperson said.

Cost of living concerns

The market behaviour noted by the AER is not allowed in Western Australia, where generators are only allowed to sell electricity to retailers at cost price.

Instead, they are paid to be available on demand, such as in times of high need — a sort of insurance policy in what's called a capacity market.

Steve Edwell is chair of the WA Economic Regulation Authority Western Australia. (ABC News: Cason Ho)

Mr Edwell acknowledged the energy market was becoming increasingly complex with the onset of renewables, which may be contributing to some market breaches.

But he warned those companies still had to ensure they "only recover their legitimate costs".

"It's important that we pay no more than we need to, and that's no more apparent than now with the cost pressures we're all facing," he said.

WA Energy Minister Amber-Jade Sanderson said it was not appropriate for her to comment on the Bluewaters case while it was being considered by the regulator, and did not respond to questions about reforms to regulation.

WA Energy Minister Amber-Jade Sanderson. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"It is my expectation that all generators operate lawfully to ensure customers are not disadvantaged," she said.

Griffin uncertainty

‘A brutal solution’: Premier defends propping up failing coal mine with $220m The WA government has extended its financial support propping up the stricken Griffin Coal mine south of Perth to protect the state's electricity supplies.

Bluewaters' alleged breach comes amid uncertainty about the future of its power plants in WA, as the coal mine that fuels them, operated by Griffin Coal, approaches the end of its government lifeline.

Indian-owned Griffin Coal has been kept afloat by $308 million in taxpayer subsidies since entering receivership in 2022, with debts of about $1.5 billion.

The WA Government has committed to ending its funding of Griffin Coal by June 2026.

Griffin Coal has continued to pay off some of its debt to Indian lenders since receiving the government payouts, raising concerns about WA taxpayer dollars being used to offset the losses of foreign investors.

title: McIlroy completes Australian Open mission even if he did not lift trophy
text:
When he arrived in Melbourne ahead of the Australian Open, Rory McIlroy would not have envisaged a 10:12am tee time to start his final round.

The Northern Irishman must have been hoping he would not need to step up to Royal Melbourne's first hole until closer to midday, which was about the time the leading contenders were scheduled to get underway.

A patchy opening three rounds left McIlroy among the earlier starters on Sunday and he was too far back to launch a genuine challenge to the leaders, finishing in a share of 14th place on 7-under-par.

Smith denied first Australian Open title A missed putt costs Cameron Smith the chance of winning his first Australian Open, as Denmark's Rasmus Neergaard-Petersen claimed a thrilling one-stroke victory at Royal Melbourne.

While McIlroy's main goal was to lift the Stonehaven Cup for the second time in his career, he still achieved another of his ambitions: helping to restore the prestige of the Australian Open.

Whether Jack Nicklaus truly meant the tournament was once golf's unofficial "fifth major" is up for debate, but some time has passed since it was regarded among the premier events on the international calendar.

The Australian Open's history and tradition have long been admired by McIlroy, who famously pipped Adam Scott by a stroke to win the 2013 edition when it was hosted by Royal Sydney.

He played an almost ambassadorial role while in Melbourne, spruiking the merits of the 121-year-old tournament at every opportunity, and his presence created a buzz around golf in Australia, not seen since Tiger Woods visited these shores.

"I think everyone really appreciated the atmosphere that they played in this week," McIlroy said on Sunday.

"Hopefully it'll be the same next year at Kingston Heath and hopefully the tournament sort of grows from here, and sort of gets back to the stature that it deserves."

Rory McIlroy was making his first Australian Open appearance in over a decade. (Getty Images: Andy Cheung)

Of course, a significant amount of money was forked out to secure McIlroy's services for consecutive Australian Open appearances (he is due to return next year).

But the investment has surely paid off across several metrics, including increased global interest and — most importantly for national governing body Golf Australia — the possibility of a financial windfall on the back of staggering attendance numbers.

More than 100,000 spectators converged on Royal Melbourne across the four rounds, with 33,408 making their way to the famous Sandbelt course on Sunday.

Every vantage point was taken to see Rory McIlroy play at Royal Melbourne. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

Speaking on Friday, McIlroy was blown away by the crowd response on the opening two days, which saw in excess of 40,000 come through the gates.

"I said to Adam [Scott] walking up in the first [hole], it didn't feel like a Friday afternoon round," McIlroy said.

"It felt like we were going out in the final group on a Sunday.

"Just that scene on the first tee was amazing. And then walking up the last [hole] and everyone's still here, and it's incredible."

Crowds flock to see McIlroy

Even though McIlroy was out of contention, the spectator gallery following the five-time major winner during his final round was heaving.

Fans crowded around the tees, lined the fairways and descended on the greens in greater numbers than those watching the lead group — consisting of winner Rasmus Neergaard-Petersen, runner-up Cameron Smith and third-placed Si Woo Kim — for much of its round.

McIlroy endeared himself to his legion of fans by politely acknowledging them and accepting their encouragement, which came via regular calls of "Go Rory!".

The reigning Masters champion even made the day of one of his youngest supporters when he gifted and signed the cap he wore during his final 18 holes.

Attracting fans was only one part of the strategy underpinning McIlroy's recruitment.

Australian Open organisers would be hoping the success of the past four days will entice a larger number of the world's best players to contest the tournament in the coming years.

Former world number five Max Homa has already expressed interest and he surely will not be alone.

A conversation with US professional Matt McCarty — who finished in a share of eighth place — convinced McIlroy more world-class players will come, given the atmosphere and quality of Australia's golf courses.

"Matt McCarty and I were talking about it out there and I said, 'What brought you down here?' McIlroy recalled.

"He said, 'The golf course. I really wanted to play a tournament at Royal Melbourne … you compare this to a majority of PGA Tour events; this is so much better.'"

Rory McIlroy did not fail to notice spectators' interest in the tournament. (Getty images: Josh Chadwick)

A congested international schedule and the jostling between competing tours creates a challenge to secure the best talent, with South Africa and Bahamas also hosting events during the past week.

McIlroy, though, is adamant the Australian Open should be the preferred option.

"If you compare this tournament to the other two tournaments going on in the world of golf this week, there's no comparison," McIlroy said on Sunday.

"Yes, the field in The Bahamas is stronger than the one here. But in terms of atmosphere, golf courses — basically everything else you're looking for in a tournament — I can't think of many better than this."

McIlroy may not have won the Australian Open, but his appearance in Melbourne will surely help put it back on the map.

title: Live: ASX down ahead of RBA rates decision this week
text:
The big news on Wall Street's Friday session was the hefty $US72 billion ($108 billion) bid Netflix pitched at another media giant, Warner Bros Discovery, a bid Warners was very happy to accept.

Warner Bros' share price jumped 6.3% on the news, while Netflix's fell 2.9%.

Paramount, a rival bidder in the chase for Warners along with Comcast, tumbled close to 10%.

Warners has been in play for some time, with the $US27.75/share bid roughly three times what the company was trading at six months ago.

That's good news for Warners's shareholders and even better news for its veteran and extremely well-paid CEO, David Zaslav, who will, according to Bloomberg, become a billionaire if the deal goes through.

However, it has a few regulatory and political hurdles it needs to clear first.

Some members of Congress have already declared Netflix's proposed acquisition of Warner Bros Discovery's studios and streaming unit an antitrust "nightmare" for consumers and creatives, while the company touted the deal as driving value for viewers, workers and shareholders.

Democrat Senator Elizabeth Warren said the deal, "Would create one massive media giant with control of close to half of the streaming market — threatening to force Americans into higher subscription prices and fewer choices over what and how they watch, while putting American workers at risk."

Fellow Democrat and co-chair of the House Monopoly Busters Caucus Pramila Jayapa called the deal a "nightmare".

"It would mean more price hikes, ads, & cookie cutter content, less creative control for artists, and lower pay for workers," she said in a post on social media site X.

There's also considerable disquiet among some important Republicans.

Senator Mike Lee, a Utah Republican who leads the antitrust committee, said a Netflix takeover of Warner Bros Discovery's streaming assets "should send alarm to antitrust enforcers around the world".

"Netflix built a great service, but increasing Netflix's dominance this way would mean the end of the Golden Age of streaming for content creators and consumers," Senator Lee wrote in a post on X.

Last month, Republican Senator Roger Marshall of Kansas and Representative Darrell Issa of California also called on US antitrust enforcers to scrutinise any possible Netflix-Warner Bros deal, saying it could lead to fewer movies in theatres.

Warner Bros Pictures Animation began its journey with the iconic Looney Tunes in 1930 and has produced classics such as The Iron Giant, The Lego Movie franchise and Happy Feet.

However, the company has been in the doldrums recently, with its profit and sales falling 5% last year.

Netflix is the giant of the streaming space, with its revenues rising about 16% to $39 billion last year. It had 301.6 million total subscribers in 2024.

With Reuters

title: 'Sadly I've got a lot more seasons with him': Piastri praised as future champ
text:
Oscar Piastri may have fallen short in his bid to become a Formula 1 world champion, but he has earned plenty of admirers this season, with many tipping him to be a future world champion.

Piastri needed a win and for his rivals, Lando Norris and Max Verstappen, to have bad weekends at the Yas Marina circuit in Abu Dhabi to have any chance of him claiming the title.

And although he managed to lead the race due to a gusty one-stop strategy call and a brilliant overtaking move over his teammate on lap one, he was unable to last the distance, finishing second to Verstappen, missing out on the title by just 13 points.

Even had Piastri won, teammate Norris was able to claim the podium spot he needed to win his first drivers' championship title.

"I think today yes [I can be satisfied]," Piastri said on Fox Sports.

"We gave it everything. We tried a bit of a gamble on strategy and tried absolutely everything to try and win the race and give ourselves the best chance to win a championship.

It didn't happen for him this year, but it seems the entire paddock believes that it is only a matter of time before Piastri claims a title of his own — especially his McLaren bosses.

Oscar Piastri passed Lando Norris on the first lap of the race around the outside of turn nine. (Getty Images: Clive Mason)

Principle engineer Andrea Stella was full of praise for the 24-year-old Australian, saying the team could have had "two champions this year".

"The gap between the two was so small," Stella said.

"Oscar was a worthwhile champion. He learned so rapidly. His trajectory is phenomenal and no doubt we have a future multiple world champion.

F1 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix Max Verstappen has won the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix ahead of Oscar Piastri, but Lando Norris finishes third to claim the world title.

"I'm just so proud being proud [being a member] of the team, is my main feeling at the moment. Being proud of everyone, and everyone responded to the call this season and the call to elevate the game compared to last season.

"The demand has been huge; two drivers in the contest and trying to do it the McLaren way, trying to be fair and respectful. It has been a lot of work.

"The team has been so united, even with bumps in the road."

Commentator and former driver Martin Brundle was clear that Piastri had all the tools to become one of the best, while former world champion Nico Rosberg said the Australian had a "superpower" that made him so impressive.

"His superpower is his mental strength. He's so level headed," the 2016 world champion said.

"There's no reason why Oscar can't turn it around next year."

Oscar Piastri came close, but not close enough, to teammate Lando Norris despite beating him in their last two races. (Getty Images: Formula 1/Bryn Lennon)

McLaren boss Zak Brown agreed.

"Both our guys won seven races, drove brilliantly, they supported each other," he said.

"It's a cruel sport how some things don't go your way when they're out of your control, but I'm excited to go racing with him [Piastri]."

Even his teammate Norris, who said Piastri had made him dig "deeper than ever before", acknowledged it would not be long before Piastri would overhaul him.

"I don't think people understand how difficult it can be — as people have proven in the past — having teammates fighting for a world championship," Norris said.

"For Zak [Brown] and Andrea [Stella] to have control over those things, it's certainly tougher than just having one car.

"We take points off of each other, we make our lives harder, strategies more difficult, but the team would always take that over only having one car performing for a world championship.

"I have to give congrats to Oscar because he's driven incredibly.

"I'm glad I've had Oscar for the last three years because, even though he's a lot newer to it than me, I've learned a lot from him and he showed me up so many times and I've managed to learn a lot from him, and I wouldn't be the driver I am today without that.

Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri celebrated at the end of the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix. (Getty Images: LAT Images/Steven Tee)

"He's made me have to dig even deeper than I ever have before.

"By the mid-point of the season he was performing better than I was and doing a better job consistently.

"At some point he's going to get the better of me because he's an incredible driver.

"I've enjoyed it, I've learned a lot.

"Sadly, I've got a lot more seasons with him in the future so I look forward to those tough moments as well."

Piastri also credited his teammate for making him a better driver and said that although he did not enjoy every moment of the season, he can't wait to resume battle next year.

"It's been a fun challenge. Obviously at certain points maybe it doesn't feel that fun," Piastri said of the season-long battle with Norris.

"I think it's been a really enjoyable season for both of us probably — and I'm saying that as the person who's not champion.

"There's plenty more years to come of intense weekends and tight battles. I think it's made both of us better drivers."

And as for the future?

"I've learned a lot of lessons on dealing with tough moments [this year]," Piastri said.

"Ultimately I've learned a lot about myself."

title: Piastri came so close, but these minor moments are what let the F1 title slip away
text:
Immediately after the season-ending Abu Dhabi Formula 1 Grand Prix, the three key combatants were ushered way from the noise and mayhem of the circuit to relax on a plush sofa behind the podium for a moment.

After spending most of the last 90 minutes racing at an average of 200km/h with a 1.6-litre, V6-hybrid engine screaming behind them, a more incongruous setting you could not imagine.

But it was here that Oscar Piastri, Max Verstappen and Lando Norris sat, largely in companionable silence.

Perhaps they were processing the 58 laps of excruciatingly tense racing they had just competed against each other.

Perhaps they were exhausted from the tension of the past few days and hours.

Perhaps they were casting their minds over the thousands of kilometres and 24 rounds of races that brought them to this point in the first place.

For the two drivers who came so close, perhaps they were wondering what might have been.

Max Verstappen and Oscar Piastri both had their chances to win the title. (Getty Images: Clive Rose)

This is a season that has taken the Formula 1 circus from Melbourne in March to Abu Dhabi in December, crisscrossing the world in the battle for global supremacy.

In the end, after so many ups and downs, the three key protagonists in the closest world title race for 15 years could only be separated by 13 measly points.

F1 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix Max Verstappen has won the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix ahead of Oscar Piastri, but Lando Norris finishes third to claim the world title.

It was Norris who claimed his first title after eight years in Formula 1, just two points ahead of four-time champion Verstappen, with Piastri third after their nerve-racking Abu Dhabi Grand Prix battle.

Piastri was, amid the fireworks and tears, the blaring music and supporters' cheers, the first man over to his teammate to congratulate him on his win.

But in his heart, he may be wondering where it went wrong for him and why those roles were not reversed.

Of the three drivers to have led the championship this year, none did so for longer than Piastri.

For 15 consecutive race weekends between Saudi Arabia and Mexico, the Aussie led the pack. After the Dutch Grand Prix in round 15, Piastri led the world title race by 34 points, with Verstappen a whopping 104 points further back.

How then, from there, did he lose it so dramatically?

Lando Norris got the chocolates this time around. Will next time be Oscar Piastri's turn? (Getty Images: Clive Mason)

Piastri had won five of the first nine races. Then, he won two of the next six, including at Zandvoort at the Dutch Grand Prix, the first race after the summer break, where Norris did not score any points at all

But then, Piastri went off the boil — he didn't win any of the last nine races of the year and missed the podium in six of them.

So where did the wheels fall off?

Was it at Monza at the Italian Grand Prix? It was there that Piastri was controversially asked to hand a position back to Norris after the British driver had a bad pit stop.

Yes, Norris had, reluctantly, done the same for Piastri at the Hungarian Grand Prix in 2024, which was Piastri's first-ever win in Formula 1.

It led to plenty of people suggesting that McLaren were favouring the Englishman over the Australian — an inferiority complex based on the painful experiences of Mark Webber being summarily relegated to second fiddle by Sebastian Vettel and Daniel Ricciardo's Verstappen woes — and that no matter how good Australian drivers are, they have to be better than their European counterparts to ever get an opportunity to fight for the biggest prize.

Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri promise plenty of battles to come. (Getty Images: Formula 1/Bryn Lennon)

Whether McLaren were favouring one driver or the other — and outside of Australia the prevailing view is that they were not — the Monza mashup clearly unsettled Piastri.

He would go on to call it "the worst weekend I've ever had in racing" after all and, the very next race in Azerbaijan, during an error-strewn weekend, Piastri crashed and retired on the first lap, his only race retirement of the season.

He finished off the podium at the next four races in Singapore, Austin, Mexico and Brazil, before both McLarens were disqualified at the Las Vegas Grand Prix, making for a rough six race weekends in a row.

Former racer and commentator Martin Brundle noted that there were a number of moments outside what he called Piastri's "fallow period" late in the season, which it was noted came just as people began talking about him as a genuine title favourite.

Oscar Piastri's bash in Baku was a major error of judgement that cost him valuable points. (Getty Images: Rudy Carezzevoli)

But he noted that there were subtle missed opportunities or mistakes throughout the season that all added up to issues.

"One rainy corner in his backyard in Melbourne, he was so unlucky to go off onto the grass and lose so many points there," Brundle noted.

Piastri lost control in the wet when running in the top few positions and dropped to 13th before recovering to finish ninth.

Then there were the two "hard penalties" that Piastri had to serve at Silverstone and in Brazil, the first for "erratic braking" under the safety car, which led to Verstappen briefly overtaking him while preparing for the restart, the second for causing an accident when he locked up and crashed into Kimi Antonelli.

Those penalties meant he finished second in Britain and fifth in Brazil, dropping more valuable points.

"Those could easily have been mitigated," Brundle said, suggesting that they could have been reduced to five-second infringements or not penalised at all.

Add the Vegas disqualification and the Qatar pit stop error — both mistakes by his team that Piastri had nothing to do with — and you can see why he'd feel hard done by.

But realistically, these mistakes are just the ebb and flow of a hard-fought season that takes place over the course of 10 gruelling months.

"There are a number of little turning points," Brundle said.

"You can't change that. He needs to work where he needs to be stronger … and draw a line under it.

"Easier said than done."

Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri hugged each other at the end. (Getty Images: Clive Rose)

Easier said then done knowing that, with new regulations coming in next year, there is no guarantee that McLaren will again be the dominant car they were this campaign.

McLaren's return to the top of Formula 1 has not been an overnight sensation — their 2024 constructors title was a first in 26 years.

Just because an ascent was hard fought, it doesn't mean that the descent will be just as gradual.

Easier said than done knowing that, just because people have hailed you as a future world champion, until your name is on the trophy and the champagne is for you and you alone, those sentiments are worthless.

Just look at his manager, Webber. He led the title race in 2010 but fell short in the closing couple of rounds. He never got another chance.

Perhaps Piastri can take solace in knowing that it was not just he who was left to rue mistakes.

Verstappen may look back on a rush of blood in Spain that cost him a 10-second penalty when he crashed into the side of George Russell's Mercedes.

That 10-second penalty essentially cost him 11 points. He finished the race 10th while he was fighting for fourth with Russell at the time of his mistake.

But Verstappen already has four world titles. He doesn't have to worry about his legacy being unfulfilled.

But there are plenty of minor moments that shape a season — it's what makes them so compelling.

And every mistake or error is a learning moment for Piastri.

Sometimes coming close makes you stronger for a tilt at the top next time around.

Sometimes it's a scar that never heals.

title: Museum faces heat over gas company sponsorship of education program
text:
The Queensland Museum has been accused of allowing a sponsorship deal with one of the world’s largest gas corporations to influence educational materials it distributed that teach students about climate change without mentioning fossil fuels.

Comms Declare, a climate advocacy group, released a report on Monday criticising the materials available for teachers to use in Queensland classrooms, which come branded with the logo of Shell QGC – the division of the multinational energy company that drills for natural gas in Queensland.

The resources cover topics including extreme weather, threatened species and ocean acidification, but omit a focus on the role of fossil fuels, including coal and gas, in driving climate change.

Queensland Museum at South Bank in Brisbane. Credit: Queensland Museum

In one example, a resource explains ocean acidification in relation to excess carbon dioxide, without identifying fossil fuels, such as coal, oil or gas combustion, as the cause.

title: Wells billed taxpayers to fly husband to two Boxing Day Tests, three Grand finals
text:
The cost of a seat in a corporate box on Grand Final day starts at $4500 per person, which suggests the potential cost of Wells’ six free grand final tickets over three years could be as much as $27,000. All of these claims are within the rules that govern family reunion flights and travel entitlements, but these latest revelations will prompt further questions about whether Wells’ use of the entitlements meet community expectations. It is not clear if Wells and her husband attended the 2025 grand final as expenses for this period have not yet been reported. Wells’ office has been contacted for comment. Earlier on Monday, this masthead revealed that in 2022 and 2024, Wells flew McCarthy from Brisbane to Melbourne under family reunion entitlements to attend the December 26 Test match, while enjoying the corporate hospitality of the sport’s governing body.

Communications and Sport Minister Anika Wells. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen The minister, who on Sunday was defending a separate use of taxpayer-funded entitlements to fly her husband and two of their three children to join her at the Thredbo ski resort this year, also flew McCarthy to Sydney for a cricket event hosted by Albanese. Wells and Albanese both defended her use of nearly $3000 in taxpayer-funded money after this masthead revealed her family had flown in to Thredbo while she undertook official business with the Australian Paralympic ski team. Under the family reunion rules, federal MPs are allowed up to three return business class flights per year for family members that are between the MP’s home base and a city other than Canberra. This is how Wells recorded the flights to the cricket, to Thredbo and to the grand finals. Loading

There is no suggestion Wells has contravened any rules, but the expenses claims raise questions about her use of entitlements and whether they are in line with “community expectations”. Wells told Sky News on Sunday in response to the Thredbo story that her claims were within the rules, but she said she could “absolutely appreciate that people have a gut reaction to these figures”. “I don’t resile from that, and that’s why I agreed that entitlements should be scrutinised. I’m happy for mine to be scrutinised,” she said, “but at the end of the day, I don’t write these rules.” Albanese told the ABC’s Insiders program it was “completely within the rules”. “There are family reunion entitlements available. All of the travel was within guidelines,” he said.

On Monday, fellow frontbencher Tanya Plibersek defended Wells on Nine’s Today. “There are so many weekends away from home, and if you’re sports minister, a lot of those are very deliberately weekend events that you’re required to attend because that’s when people watch sport. That’s when people play sport. She was in Thredbo to highlight the extra investment we’re making in the Paralympics.” Anika Wells and Anthony Albanese both defended the Thredbo trip. Credit: Alex Ellinghausen More than $4000 for three cricket trips During the 2022-23 Test cricket series against South Africa, Wells charged taxpayers for family reunion flights on December 26, so McCarthy could fly between Brisbane and Melbourne in one day. The two flights cost $1885.29. Wells also received three free corporate tickets from Cricket Australia.

In the 2023-24 season against Pakistan, Wells received only one free ticket to attend the Boxing Day Test. She did not charge taxpayers for her husband to fly to Melbourne that year. However, taxpayers were hit just a few days later, when Wells spent another $1274.72 for two more family reunion flights between Brisbane and Sydney, on January 1, so McCarthy could join her at Albanese’s reception for the Australian and Pakistani teams at Kirribilli House. During the 2024-25 season, Wells charged taxpayers for reunion flights that cost $983.82 so that McCarthy could fly return from Brisbane to Melbourne to join her at the MCG on December 26. The couple were guests of Cricket Australia. Loading The total cost to taxpayers for all flights was $4183.83 over three years, according to the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority website, and on all three occasions, the sports minister and her husband had been together for just one day.

The MCG charges up to $995 per person for a seat in a corporate box, which means the potential value of the six free tickets from Cricket Australia could be nearly $6000. Sports ministers and their opposition counterparts frequently attend high-profile events as guests of sporting organisations, and their attendance at these events is in keeping with the “dominant purpose” test, which determines whether an MP’s travel is appropriate. Wells said the hospitality she received from Cricket Australia is in line with the rules of parliament’s register of members’ interests. Wells under pressure as social media ban looms Wells has been under pressure since last week following revelations of the full cost of Wells’ ministerial trip to the United Nations General Assembly in September to showcase the social media ban for children.

It then emerged she had claimed $3600 in travel entitlements for trips to Adelaide, where she attended a friend’s birthday party as well as conducting official business; three trips to France in one year as sports minister at a combined cost $116,000, and the $2845.50 Thredbo family reunion. A government spokesman said: “The travel was in accordance with guidelines and in capacity as minister for sport.” The spokesman did not answer questions about why Wells needed to have three one-day reunions with her husband, whether the minister would repay any of the expenses claimed, or whether the trips met community expectations. The minister’s use of family reunion flights is similar to an Uluru trip that Tony Burke took in 2012, while environment minister, when he charged taxpayers close to $9000 so his wife and children could join him. Burke’s claim was also within the rules, but when details of the trip emerged in 2015, he said the trip was “beyond community expectations” and in 2020 paid the costs back.

Opposition finance spokesman James Paterson said Wells’ travel and entitlement usage “failed the kitchen table test”. “She’s a minister who is not just out of touch with Australians, but she’s out of touch with reality,” Paterson said. In 2017, Opposition Leader Sussan Ley had to resign from her position then as health minister in the Turnbull government when it was revealed she had bought an apartment on the Gold Coast while on official trips. title: When the party’s over: why you ‘break’ emotionally and physically at year’s end
text:
The people who hold it all together tend to break hardest when they finally stop.

Being the “strong one” becomes expected of them — it’s easier to keep going than admit overwhelm. Emotional labour, caregiving, household logistics, unresolved trauma, invisible responsibility… all of it accumulates quietly until it becomes physically impossible to maintain.

Younger Australians are feeling it too, with three in four workers under 25 quietly cracking, compared with 35.7 per cent of those over 55, according to the ‘2025 Australia Workplace Report’. It’s a cross-generational pressure cooker: adults stretched thin by responsibility, younger workers strained by uncertainty.

“For people who have substance use issues, complex relationships or childhood trauma, Christmas can be a time where the increased stress, expectations and family contact become overwhelming or lead to crisis,” explains Sutton. “It’s also a time of evaluation, offering a new year and an opportunity to focus on holistic recovery, addressing physical, emotional and spiritual well-being.”

Coping culture and the slide into numbing

When pressure builds and emotional space disappears, people turn to coping mechanisms without realising it: another drink, another late-night email, another overloaded week.

“At Byron Private, we see people who have turned to alcohol, food or over-functioning because these behaviours give quick relief from stress or uncomfortable emotions,” Meighan says. “High stress dulls self-awareness. Coping becomes automatic before they recognise the long-term toll.”

The distinction between “coping” and “numbing” is subtle but crucial.

“Coping is intentional and restorative, such as a walk, a conversation, journaling, boundaries,” she explains. “Numbing is avoidance. It may feel good temporarily but doesn’t address the underlying issue.”

December is the perfect social enabler: indulgence without guilt, excess framed as normal, emotional load wrapped in celebrations and primed for collapse.

Recognising the patterns early can prevent escalation. “Awareness is the foundation for change,” explains Kim. Credit: Byron Private

When stopping makes everything catch up

The crash isn’t weakness; it’s biology. Many people run on stress hormones for most of the year. When the external pressure lifts, the body finally releases vigilance.

“People often hold out until a safe point, like the holidays,” Meighan says. “Once they get there, their system collapses precisely because it finally can.”

What happens next is all too familiar for many:

the adrenaline drop, which can leave people exhausted, weepy or ill

deferred emotions rising because the brain finally feels safe enough to release them

a cognitive hangover, where the mind struggles to shift gears and feels numb or flat

This is what some call the “December Mirror”, the moment when all the emotions and unmet needs that have been shelved for 12 months finally demand attention.

It’s no coincidence that people who have been “quietly cracking” are 6.2 times more likely to burn out, a statistic that mirrors what Meighan sees every year.

“Stopping signals safety,” she explains. “But that can look like tears, irritability or total shutdown before rest actually begins.”

Shane adds: When stress responses are frequently activated, such as from overly anxious behaviour, it can prevent the body from fully recovering and result in emotional exhaustion.

The shift toward conscious recovery

There is a growing cultural shift away from numbing and toward conscious recovery, healing the root causes rather than escaping them.

“Trauma-informed recovery focuses on safety and understanding why the coping behaviour developed,” Meighan says. “Removing the behaviour alone often leaves someone vulnerable. Recovery is about building resilience, not just stopping drinking or working too much.”

True recovery, she says, is not stepping away from life, but “building a life you don’t need to escape from.”

It’s also deeply personal:

recognising red flags early

naming overwhelm without judgement

practising self-compassion

building sustainable coping tools

asking for support before collapse, not after

“And for someone reading this who recognises themselves, recognising these patterns early can prevent escalation,” Meighan adds, “the first gentle step is simply noticing what’s happening. Acknowledge you’re overwhelmed and deserve care. That awareness is the foundation for change.”

The festive season will always ask something of us. But as more Australians recognise the emotional cost of running on empty, a new wellbeing movement is emerging: one centred in compassion, prevention, and understanding what our bodies and minds have been trying to tell us all year.

Byron Private is an integrated, trauma-informed recovery centre helping individuals with complex lives restore balance and resilience through personalised, evidence-based clinical care for mental health and addiction.
